attr.q: Let (a_n) be a bounded sequence.
Prove that the sequence defined by y_n = \sup\{ a_k : k \geq n \} converges.
attr.a: (y_n) decreases. It's bounded too. Hence converges.

attr.q: Prove that \lim \inf a_n \leq \lim \sup a_n for every bounded sequence, and give an example of a sequence for which the inequality is strict.
attr.a:
\inf \{ a_k \} \leq \sup \{ a_k \} by definition.

\inf \{ a_k \} < \sup \{ a_k \} holds when (a_n) is 1, -1, 1, -1, 1, -1 \dots

attr.q: Show that \lim \inf a_n \leq \lim \sup a_n if and only if \lim a_n exists. In this case, all three share the same value.
attr.a:
Every a_n is supermum of some starting point a_m, e.i, \sup \{ a_m, a_{m+1}, \dots, a_n, a_{n+1} \dots \} such that m < n.

Every supermum \sup \{ a_m, a_{m+1}, \dots, a_n, a_{n+1} \dots \} is decided by some value a_n such that m < n.

attr.q:
The limit superior of (a_n), or \lim \sup a_n, is defined by

\lim \sup a_n = \lim y_n

where y_n is the sequence from part (a) of this exercise. Provide a reasonable definition for \lim \inf a_n and briefly explain why it always exists for any bounded sequence.
attr.a:
A reasonable definition for \lim \inf a_n would be y_n = \inf {a_k : k \geq n}.

Limit exists because it's increasing and bounded.
